tossups.question: In an experiment by Watanabe et al., these animals could be trained to tell apart Picasso and Monet paintings, and Herbranson and Schroeder found that these animals were not fooled by the Monty Hall problem. Criticizing an experiment using these animals, Staddon and Simmelhag distinguished terminal responses from interim responses. That experiment noted these animals’ “superstition,” since they would continue to perform whatever action they happened to be doing when (*) food was released at 15-second intervals. That experiment placed them in a box named after the experimenter, who used them to study operant conditioning. These animals were trained to play ping-pong and guide missiles by a behaviorist who wrote Beyond Freedom and Dignity. For 10 points, name these birds used in many experiments by B. F. Skinner.
tossups.answer: pigeons [or Columba livia domestica; prompt on “birds”]

tossups.question: In an analysis of another thinker’s work, this book calls the Fall a “natural accident” and discusses a period of pleasure and desire called “the festival,” after which incest was prohibited. Robert Laporte inspired the name of its section La Brisure, which means both “the joint” and “the break.” This work’s study of Emile and Confessions appears in the section “That Dangerous Supplement.” Levi-Strauss’s Tristes Tropiques is analyzed in this book’s Part II, (*) “Nature, Culture, and Writing,” which takes as its focus the “Essay on the Origin of Languages.” This work, originally an unsuccessful doctoral thesis, critiques Saussure’s structuralism and introduced the terms “logocentricity” and “differance.” For 10 points, name this foundational work of deconstruction by Jacques Derrida.
tossups.answer: Of Grammatology [or De la grammatologie] Bonuses:

tossups.question: A rebellion among workers of this good resulted when they became angry at being fed oatmeal, canned peaches, and brown rice in the cafeteria, and those workers of it had to go to an “island of innocence” to access bars and brothels. A fervent promoter of it in Singapore became known as “Mad Ridley.” A group that used a whip made out of hippopotamus hide called the chicotte sought to maximize production of this good. The “American Village” housed workers of it in a failed utopian city called (*) “Fordlandia.” Quotas for producing this good were enforced by a Leon Rom-led group that brutally severed the hands of workers. This good was produced under the coercion of the Force Publique in the Belgian Congo. The process of vulcanization greatly increased demand for this good. For 10 points, name this latex good that can be extracted from trees to make tires.
tossups.answer: rubber [or caoutchouc; prompt on “latex” until mention]

tossups.question: In this novel, Mr. de Villiers is told that more schooling will create smarter criminals. In this novel, a child on a red horse visits the protagonist’s house and tries to learn his language. A dialogue repeating “Have you a room that you could let?” begins a chapter of this novel, in which long waitlists for houses force the building of a shanty town. A character in this novel donates (*) milk to a village after trying to understand his dead son’s admiration for Abraham Lincoln. This novel is named for a request that the “unborn child … not love the earth too deeply.” Its protagonist receives a telegram from Theophilus Msimangu before discovering that his son killed Arthur Jarvis. For 10 points, Stephen Kumalo tries to prevent the hanging of his son Absalom in what Alan Paton novel?

In one novel, a man with this occupation watches a “fire festival” and thinks about “millions of lives” succeeding one another like waves. That man plans to “seduce everyone and everything, even history” before his lover drowns himself. Another character with this occupation addresses memoirs to the future after reading a prophecy about “hairy men” and writes a parody about gambling that is taken seriously. A letter to Mark makes up a Marguerite Yourcenar novel titled for the (*) “Memoirs” of a person with this occupation. Another character with this occupation loves the prostitute Calpurnia and hides behind a curtain; that historian is perpetually seen as “a fool” but survives the scheming of Livia. Robert Graves wrote a fictional autobiography about a stammering one of these people. For 10 points, name this occupation of Hadrian and Claudius.

Initiates into Santeria have herbs and this substance rubbed onto their heads by their Padrino. A Yoruban deity of this substance formed the Iyami Aje after the male creator gods ignored her as they made the world. The most basic altar in vodou consists of a candle and some of this substance. A wife of Shango whose main color is yellow is a goddess of this substance; her name is (*) Oshun. In some belief systems, the dead reside in Guinea under a large amount of this substance. Because Vodou is influenced highly by Catholicism, baptism of infants involves the use of this substance. For 10 points, name this liquid element that is used in many rituals and is associated with river and sea deities.

This play’s stage directions describe a room in which “weariness has … won” and “everything has been polished … too often.” One man in this play complains that when men say they have a dream, women just respond, “Eat your eggs.” Bev and Russ grieve Kenneth’s suicide in a prequel-slash-sequel to this play by Bruce Norris. A girl is forced to repeat, “In my mother’s house there is still God” after declaring her intent to go to (*) med school in this play. Bobo reveals that Willy has absconded with money in this play, in which Joseph Asagai tries to convince Beneatha to move to Africa. Instead of purchasing a liquor store, a $10,000 life insurance check is used to buy a house for Ruth and Walter in the all-white Clybourne Park neighborhood. For 10 points, name this work about the Younger family which takes its name from “A Dream Deferred,” by Lorraine Hansberry.

An essay about this battle begins by stating “this is a simple story of a battle; such a tale as may be told by a soldier who is no writer to a reader who is no soldier”; that Ambrose Bierce essay is titled “What I Saw of [this battle].” Bogged down by a storm, the head Confederate general at this battle did not launch a night attack, allowing Union reinforcements to arrive from Crump’s Landing. It ended with a Confederate raid on Fallen Timbers, where Nathan Bedford Forrest survived a shot to the pelvis. At this battle, Daniel (*) Ruggles packed 50 cannons into a position referred to as the Hornet’s Nest. Reinforcements led by Don Carlos Buell turned the tide at this battle, where P. G. T. Beauregard took over the Confederate army after Albert Sidney Johnston’s death. For 10 points, name this 1862 victory for Ulysses S. Grant’s Union army, fought in southwestern Tennessee.
tossups.answer: the Battle of Shiloh [or the Battle of Pittsburg Landing]

tossups.question: One of these functional groups lies adjacent to a quaternary carbon in the antifungal terbinafine. As ligands, these compounds can act as either two- or four-electron donors. In the presence of nickel catalysts these compounds can trimerize into arenes. When they’re hydroxylated they instantly transform into carbonyls by tautomerization. Two equivalents of hydrogen bromide can be used to transform them into (*) geminal halides. Reacting these compounds with sodium metal dissolved in liquid ammonia gives the trans-alkene product, and they can be transformed into cis-alkenes via Lindlar’s catalyst. These compounds contain two sp-hybridized carbons linked by one sigma and two pi bonds. For 10 points, name this functional group that contains a carbon-carbon triple bond.

This deity was so bright that soldiers could only see him from behind their shields, so the bravest warriors with the most arrow holes in their shields saw him best. This god fought the rebellion of his sister’s son Copil and ordered that his heart be thrown into a lake, and this deity’s attendant was Paynal. This god created the moon by killing his sister and throwing her head into the air. The Four (*) Hundred Southerners tried to kill this wielder of the Turquoise Serpent, who was often depicted as blue. This god was born when a ball of feathers impregnated his mother Coatlicue (co-at-LI-kway). This brother of Tezcatlipoca and Quetzalcoatl helped his people settle in a place where an eagle sat on a cactus, which later became Tenochtitlan. For 10 points, name this Aztec god of war and recipient of human sacrifices, who was represented as a hummingbird.

Bataille argues that this painting reduces its main character to brushstrokes on canvas to create a sense of sacredness in the death of the subject. One figure in this painting is called “a robot conveniently made to disappear … castrata and whore” in an essay by Lorraine O’Grady, and Emile Zola said that while other artists “lie,” this painting’s artist “asked himself, why not tell the truth.” The title person of this painting sits between a bright red table and a vase of flowers and is dramatically (*) unveiled to the appreciation of a man with a cane and a top hat in a “Modern” version. The model for The Railway, Victorine Meurent, poses in the style of Venus of Urbino in this painting. It aroused controversy due to the confrontational gaze of its prostitute subject. For 10 points, name this painting by Edouard Manet, depicting a black servant bringing flowers to a nude white woman.

Description acceptable. The “30 years” movement of Charles Alkan’s Grande Sonata is named after this subject. The fourth movement of Prokofiev’s The Fiery Angel alludes to this subject as a brief comic relief. Although it’s not part of Songs and Dances of Death, Modest Mussorgsky wrote a song that was inspired by this subject for soprano voice, although it is now mostly sung by bass. The opening theme of another work inspired by this subject contains the (*) first published example of twelve tone row in Western music. The composer of that work later added a “Chorus Mysticus” section to its finale, which also shares its name with the finale of Mahler’s Symphony of a Thousand. For 10 points, name this German legend in which a scholar makes a deal with the devil in exchange for unlimited knowledge.
tossups.answer: Damnation of Faust [or Doctor Faustus; or redemption of Faust; accept anything that indicates that it’s the Faust mythos; antiprompt on Gretchen or Mephistopeles]

tossups.question: At the end of a 1958 film, this actress looks down at a corpse floating in the Rio Grande and states “What does it matter what you say about people?” The third section of Laura Mulvey’s “Visual Pleasure and Narrative Cinema” contrasts Hitchcock’s depictions of women with a certain director’s treatment of this actress. This actress, who played an aging prostitute in Orson Welles’ Touch of Evil, performed the song “Falling in Love Again” in a 1930 film that inspired Paramount Studios to offer her a contract and cast her as (*) nightclub singers in films like Morocco and Shanghai Express. In an adaptation of a novel written by Thomas Mann’s brother, Heinrich, this actress plays a cabaret singer who seduces a professor played by Emil Jannings. Josef von Sternberg launched the career of, for 10 points, what German actress who played Lola in The Blue Angel?

LANCE is a FRET-based assay that can be used for in-vitro detection of this molecule. High levels of this molecule are required for the stalk and spore maturation in D. discoideum. The heart failure medications cilostazol and milrinone work by inhibiting an enzyme that breaks down this molecule. Forskolin can increase intracellular concentration of this molecule. Like calcium, this molecule can activate a class of (*) guanine nucleotide exchange factors such as Epac2. In bacteria, this molecule can bind to catabolite activator protein in response to low glucose levels, which in turn promotes transcription of lac operon. For 10 points, name this signaling molecule, a second messenger that is formed from ATP by adenylate cyclase.

Note: Description Acceptable The editor of a newspaper supporting this movement was convicted of libel after making an allegation of bribery against Auguste Burdeau. This movement took a hit when a supporter called the Marquis de Mores killed an army captain, leading to this movement’s distinction between two types of “swords.” The newspaper La Libre Parole was a chief proponent of this movement under Edouard Drumont. The involvement of Cornelius Herz in a corruption scandal provided ammunition for this attitude in the Panama Affair. Georges (*) Picquart discovered that documents were forged by a supporter of this sentiment named Ferdinand Esterhazy. An article opposing this attitude was published in L’Aurore and was named “J’Accuse.” For 10 points, what sentiment helped convict Alfred Dreyfus of treason?
tossups.answer: anti-Semitism [accept anything involving disliking or hating Jews; accept opposition to Dreyfus or anti-Dreyfusards]

tossups.question: Shifting the states of this system by x-sub-0 corresponds to the energy levels of cyclotron orbits in Landau quantization. A constant times the exponent of negative q squared over 2 gives the psi-sub-zero of this system, whose coherent states are named for Glauber. A pair of matrices whose superdiagonal and subdiagonal elements are the square roots of the natural numbers are used to move between (*) energy levels of this system; those are symbolized a and a-dagger and are called the ladder operators. The energies of this system, whose wavefunctions contain the Hermite polynomials, are spaced h-bar times omega, and its potential is given by Hooke’s law. For 10 points, name this quantum system, a generalization of a mass on a spring.
tossups.answer: quantum harmonic oscillator [or QHO; prompt on “oscillator”, “harmonic oscillator” or “simple harmonic oscillator”]

tossups.question: Xenophon claims that the destruction of one of these structures was accompanied by “the music of flute girls.” According to Plutarch, the spoils from the battle of the Eurymedon River were used to construct one of them. A prophecy that these things would save the Greeks was successfully interpreted to mean ships before the Battle of Salamis. One of these structures was rebuilt after Conon won the Battle of Cnidus during the Corinthian War. One of them received its greatest use during a (*) period named for Archidamus, and it connected to Phaleron. The first of these in their city was built by Themistocles after some hostage-taking trickery. The greatest of these was destroyed by the Spartans at the end of the Peloponnesian War and provided access to the Port of Piraeus. For 10 points, name these defensive structures which included a “Long” one defending Athens.

In this works opening number, a character claims that his “admiration for [the main character] hasn’t died.” One character in this work is confronted by a crowd desperately begging for his assistance, prompting him to angrily exclaim “Heal yourselves!” Another character in this work sings to the protagonist about how he is “all [they] they talk about / the wonder of the year.” In one scene of this work, a group of the antagonists sing about how the protagonist (*) must die. A 1973 film adaptation of this work contains numerous anachronisms such as guards holding machine guns. In one of the songs of this work, the main protagonist has a vision of a dead character singing to him about how “Israel in 4 BC had no mass communication.” For ten points, what Andrew Lloyd Webber rock opera centers around the final days of the Messiah?

If a class of objects named after this mathematician are simply connected, then they must be isomorphic to either another object named for this man, the complex plane, or the unit disk. Those objects are also the subject of a theorem he co-names with Roch. A problem named for this mathematician can be generalized to involve all Dirichlet L-functions. His namesake (*) surfaces are connected complex manifolds of dimension one. A function named for this mathematician was expressed as an infinite product over the primes by Euler. That function evaluates to pi squared over 6 at two and to zero at all negative even integers. For 10 points, name this German mathematician whose namesake hypothesis is a Millennium Prize problem.

The epilogue of this novel describes the married lives of its three central couples; one husband calls his wife his basil plant, since basil “was a plant that flourished wonderfully on a murdered man’s brains.” A Nazarene painter in this novel delights at the “antithesis” of an antique statue being looked at by “beauty in its breathing life,” and Naumann resolves to paint the “Quaker”-like woman as a nun. That woman’s husband spends their honeymoon reading in the (*) Vatican Library. A character in this novel tries to settle his gambling debts by selling a horse he buys at a fair, but fails terribly and is forced to ask Mr. Garth for money. After Fred develops typhoid, the young new doctor’s frequent visits create gossip that results in Tertius Lydgate somewhat unwillingly marrying Rosamond Vincy. For 10 points, name this novel about “provincial life,” by George Eliot.

bonuses.leadin: Prime Minister Ben Chifley brought migrant workers to work on this project. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this system of 16 dams, a complex hydroelectric system in Kosciuszko National Park. William Hudson was the chief engineer of this project, and it utilized its country’s first transistorized computer.

The Snowy Mountains scheme took place in this country, which was led by John Curtain during World War II under its Labor Party. After losing the Philippines, the U.S. military was based in its city of Brisbane.
This person relaxed the racist “White Australia” immigration policy in part to help build the Snowy Mountains scheme. This Prime Minister more famously disappeared while swimming at Cheviot Beach.

bonuses.leadin: A woman forms the base of a lamp being turned on and off by a man in one work by this person, while a tiny woman picks berries between the books on a bookshelf in another work. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this German-Argentinian photographer, the creator of many creepy Dream photocollages for the column “Psychoanalysis Will Help You” and the first half of graphic design firm ringl + pit.

A dream inspired this artist’s work “Two Children are Threatened by a Nightingale,” in which a man on the roof of a house reaches for a knob on the picture frame. This German Surrealist created grattage and frottage.
Henry Fuseli painted this work in which an incubus sits on top of a languishing woman while a horse pokes its head through a red curtain.

bonuses.leadin: This poem exhorts “Suffer on, courageous millions! Suffer for a better world!” For 10 points each:
answer: “The Song of the Bell” [or “The Lay of the Bell”; or “Das Lied von der Glocke”]
parts: Name this German Romantic poem, which addresses “thou beauteous godly lightning, Daughter of Elysium” that “coaxes flowers from the buds” and “drives the wheel.”
“Ode to Joy” was written by this author of plays such as The Robbers, The Bride of Messina and Wallenstein.

This Schiller poem details the creation of the title object, which is cast in wax, filled in the ground, released from its mold, and named Concordia. It describes the destruction of a fire and a peaceful evening.

bonuses.leadin: Much of this movement responded directly to practices advocated by Lewis Binford and his “New Archaeologists.” For 10 points each:
answer: post-processual archaeology [or the interpretative archaeologies; do NOT accept “post-post-processual archaeology” or “processual archaeology”]
parts: Name this movement in archaeological theory advanced by scholars like Ian Hodder in response to the charge that earlier archaeologists were too deterministic in their evaluation of how environment shapes human behavior.

Post-processual archaeologists often oppose this school of thought emphasizing direct observation. It shares its name with a stance saying all knowledge is derived from nature, which includes the Vienna Circle’s “logical” form.
One of Lewis Binford’s most famous papers, titled “Archaeology as [this subject],” sought to enlarge archaeology’s scope to analyzing ancient society’s humans, which this field of study would cover.

bonuses.leadin: These tribes were named for the children of Jacob. For 10 points each:
answer: the Twelve Tribes of Israel [prompt on incomplete answer]
the Tribe of Joseph [or the House of Joseph or Beit Yosef]
parts: Name this group consisting of a certain number of tribes, each named after a child of Leah, Rachel, Zilpah, or Bilhah.

This original tribe was later split into two tribes, that of Ephraim and Manasseh. This tribe descended from its namesake Israelite and Asenath, and some scholars have argued that it included Jacob’s son Benjamin.
This tribe was divided into the Hanochites, the Palluites, the Hezronites, and the Carmites. It joined with the tribe of Gad to request land east of Jordan for their pasturing needs.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about STED microscopy, for 10 points each:
parts: STED falls in this general category of microscopy that beats the diffraction limit. Structured illumination and the 4pi microscope are two ways to achieve it.
STED microscopy can be performed using a biomarker of this color of fluorescent protein, originally isolated from jellyfish. It has an emission peak at 509 nm.
This process involves shining a laser on or chemically altering a fluorescent molecule to render it non-fluorescent. FRAP takes advantage of this phenomenon to study diffusion through cell membranes.

bonuses.leadin: The text of this treaty was translated into English by United States Consul-General Joel Barlow, who may have amended its controversial Article 11 without his superiors’ permission. For 10 points each:
answer: Treaty of Tripoli [or Treaty of Peace and Friendship between the United States of America and the Bey and Subjects of Tripoli of Barbary]
parts: Name this treaty, ratified by the Senate in 1797, whose Article 11 states that “the Government of the United States of America is not, in any sense, founded on the Christian religion.”

Five years after the ratification of the Treaty of Tripoli, this president expressed a similar sentiment in a letter describing “a wall of separation between church and state.” This Virginian was also the third U.S. President.
Jefferson first referred to the “wall of separation” in a celebrated 1802 letter addressed to the Baptists of this Connecticut town.

bonuses.leadin: The protagonist of this novel initially claims he is not interested in politics, but after an imaginary conversation with Tsar Nicholas II, concludes that “there is no such thing as an apolitical man.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novel about a man who forgives his wife for having a child with another man after he is falsely imprisoned for murdering a Christian boy during Passover.

The Fixer is by this Jewish author who wrote about Leo Finkle’s dealings with the marriage broker Pinye Salzman in The Magic Barrel. Harriet Bird shoots the protagonist with a silver bullet in his best-known novel.
In that novel, The Natural, Roy Hobbs is a player of this sport. While playing this sport, he breaks “Wonderboy” and injures Iris Lemon.

bonuses.leadin: Name some things about robot kinematics, for 10 points each:
parts: These things contribute to the degrees of freedom of a robotic linkage. They can be revolute or prismatic, depending on whether they have rotational or linear motion, and they are found in the robot’s “wrist” and “elbow.”

In robot velocity kinematics, the robot’s joint velocities are multiplied by this matrix to find the end effector’s linear and angular velocity in 3D space. In general, this matrix contains all the partial derivatives of a vector function.

To do path planning for moving a robot arm through a cluttered area, one of these constructs is defined over the workspace. It typically goes to infinity around obstacles so the robot takes the easiest path towards its global minimum at the goal.

bonuses.leadin: This woman was told that she looked like a ewe being fought over by two rams. For 10 points each:
answer: calf [or cow or other specific types of cow]
parts: Name this woman, who threw herself to her death from the chariot that was being used to convey her to Eogan mac Durthacht, whom she would be forced to marry.
The really sad story of Deirdre comes from the Red Branch cycle, a collection of myths from this island. Cu Chulainn is another mythological figure from this place.
Deirdre predicted the lovely red lips of her future beloved, Naoise, when she saw a freshly killed one of these animals from her room when she was young.

bonuses.leadin: This work distinguishes between Faust and Don Juan; the former only seduces one woman, the second 1,003. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this work written using four pseudonyms, including Victor Eremita and Johannes. Its various “authors” offer reflections on art and beauty as well as ethical and moral issues.
Either/Or was the first published work of this Danish author of The Sickness Unto Death, who wrote about the sacrifice of Isaac in Fear and Trembling.

This section of Either/Or praises what is “interesting,” and appeals to the role of chance in the author’s efforts. John Updike called it “a feverishly intellectual attempt to reconstruct an erotic failure as a pedagogic success.”

bonuses.leadin: This document was discovered in Geneva by Jules Nicole. For 10 points each:
answer: Book of the Prefect [or Eparchikon Biblion]
Alexios [or Alexius; Alexios Komnenos; Alexios Angelos; Alexios I, III, or IV]
parts: Name this text compiled under Emperor Leo the Wise that provided economic regulations for the overseer of the city of Constantinople. This guide is one of our most important sources on the Byzantine economy.
Most of the chapters of the Book of the Prefect provide regulations for these institutions. These organizations were generally associations of craftsmen in a particular trade.

The Byzantine economy was damaged by the sack of Constantinople in the 4th Crusade, which pitted two emperors of this name against each other. The requests of the first emperor of this name triggered the First Crusade.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about moons that are not Earth's, for 10 points each:
parts: This largest moon of Jupiter's is also the largest moon in the Solar System and was discovered by Galileo. It is going to be visited by the JUICE probe.
This ice-covered moon of Saturn is notable for its many geysers and cryovolcanoes. Plumes from this moon are the source of the E ring.
This geological feature is found on the western half of Neptune's moon Triton. It is thought to have been caused by diapirism.

bonuses.leadin: This author wrote arguably the world’s shortest story: “When he woke up, the dinosaur was still there.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author of short short stories such as “The Black Sheep” and “The Tortoise and Achilles.” His only novel, The Rest is Silence, depicts the life of Eduardo Torres from many sources.
Monterroso was a participant in this 1960s-1970s Latin American movement, which included Gabriel Garcia Marquez, among others.

This other Boom writer of Hopscotch also wrote short stories, describing a haunting in “House Taken Over,” a man turning into the title creature in “Axolotl,” and Michel photographing a seduction in “Blow-Up.”

bonuses.leadin: In the Pavement song “Range Life,” Stephen Malkmus describes this other band as “nature boys with no function,” before remarking “I don’t understand what they mean/And I could really give a fuck.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this band whose lead singer, Billy Corgan, responded to Malkmus’ perceived slight by getting Pavement banned from Lollapalooza.

In the Pavement song “Stereo,” Malkmus asks: “the voice of Geddy Lee/how did it get so high/I wonder if he speaks like an ordinary guy?” Geddy Lee is the lead singer of this band, responsible for songs like “The Spirit of Radio” and “YYZ” [pronounced “WHY-WHY-ZED].

The chorus of Pavement’s song “Silence Kit” borrows the melody of this Buddy Holly song, whose lyrics describe a feeling “going faster than a roller coaster.” Its refrain states “love like yours will surely come my way.”

bonuses.leadin: Jose Nunez de Caceres declared this country’s “Ephemeral Independence,” which was crushed by Jean-Pierre Boyer. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country that later achieved independence by a secret society called La Trinitaria led by Juan Pablo Duarte. Its leader Buenaventura Baez tried to get Ulysses S. Grant to annex this country.

The Dominican Republic was one of many Caribbean countries that produced this good, a leg of the Triangle Trade. This chief good produced by slaves in the Caribbean was usually cultivated in cane fields.
In the Dominican Republic, slaves lived on these settlements at sugar mills. Many seasonal Haitian sugar workers settled in these villages instead of returning to Haiti.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about music inspired by Judaism:
parts: This work by Ernest Bloch was planned to be a vocal work based on Ecclesiastes before the composer decided to rewrite it for Alexandre Barjansky. It is part of Bloch’s Jewish Cycle and is subtitled “Rhapsodie Hébraïque.”

In the beginning of Schelomo, this instrument plays a lengthy cadenza representing King Solomon’s reaction to the surrounding world. Max Bruch’s Kol Nidrei was also written for this instrument and the orchestra.
This composer premiered his Kaddish Symphony with the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra. This long time conductor of New York Phil may be better known for composing the opera Candide.

bonuses.leadin: This poem describes “the monstrous anger of the guns” and “the stuttering rifles’ rapid rattle.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this anti-World War I poem, which asks “What passing-bells for these who die as cattle?” and describes at “each slow dusk a drawing-down of blinds.”
“Anthem for Doomed Youth” was written by this poet who evoked “an ecstasy of fumbling” with gas helmets and criticized “the old lie” of dying for one’s country in “Dulce et Decorum Est.”

In contrast, this pro-WWI poet wrote of “some corner of a foreign field / That is forever England” in “The Soldier.” He also wrote “Well this side of Paradise! There’s little comfort in the wise” in “Tiare Tahiti.”

bonuses.leadin: RIKEN developed the MDGRAPE-3 supercomputer for conducting these simulations, which can be conducted on a GPU using Abalone. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this type of N-body simulation which models the movement of small groups of atoms. In these algorithms, Newton’s equations of motions are solved for atoms suspended in a force field.

Part of the AMBER force field involves computing the non-bonding energy by summing electrostatic interactions and these interactions, which occur between dipoles. London dispersion forces are a subset of them.
Car-Parrinello molecular dynamics adds electronic degrees of freedom back to a system that has undergone this approximation, in which electron movement and nuclear movement are separated.

bonuses.leadin: A photographer from this city gained his nickname for regularly beating ambulances to crime scenes. For 10 points each:
answer: naked [both Weegee’s book and Dassin’s film are titled The Naked City]
parts: Name this city where Arthur Fellig, more popularly known as “Weegee,” photographed many graphic crime scenes. A Jonathan Drew photograph taken in this city depicts a person plummeting face-first from a skyscraper.
Another creepy New York City photograph, Diane Arbus’ Child with Toy Hand Grenade, was taken in this Manhattan landmark. This urban park was designed by Frederick Law Olmstead.

Two recently arrested men hide their faces from the camera on the cover image of a Weegee book titled for a City described by this adjective. A 1948 Jules Dassin film noir titled for a city with this adjective ends with the narrator stating “there are 8 million stories in the [this adjective] city. This has been one of them.”
